shortname: Consumption of fixed capital of corporations
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL] for methodological explanations.
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1995–1999: imputed value. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Consumption of fixed capital
simpledes: Consumption of fixed capital of national economy is the decline in total value of fixed assets (e.g. roads, machines) which are owned and used by a producer. In other words, the amounts required to maintain the quality of fixed assets from a year to another. The decline in  value is a result of physical deterioration, normal obsolescence or normal accidental damage.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2019: imputed value. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). shortname: Gross domestic product
simpledes: Gross domestic product is the total value of goods and services produced by the national economy.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://unstats.un.org/unsd/snaama/Introduction.asp[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]United Nations National Accounts Main Aggregates Database[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: We use the GDP level in 2018 from: [URL][URL_LINK]http://unstats.un.org/unsd/snaama/Introduction.asp[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]United Nations National Accounts Main Aggregates Database[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. Then we cumulate growth rates from the following sources; 1970–2019: [URL][URL_LINK]http://unstats.un.org/unsd/snaama/Introduction.asp[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]United Nations National Accounts Main Aggregates Database[/URL_TEXT][/URL].

shortname: Net domestic product
simpledes: Net domestic product is the total value of the goods and services produced in a country, minus the value of the fixed capital used up in production (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads).The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net domestic product]=[Gross domestic product]-[Consumption of fixed capital of national economy]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2019: estimated from other components. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Net foreign income
simpledes: Net foreign income is the difference between the total value of a country's citizens and companies earned abroad, and the total value of foreign citizens and overseas companies earned in that country.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net foreign income]=[Property income received from abroad]-[Property income paid abroad]+[Compensation of employees received from abroad]-[Compensation of employees paid to rest of the world]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2013–2019: extrapolated from last available year; 1995–2012: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1990–1994: extrapolated from last available year; 1984–1989: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1978–1983: extrapolated from last available year; 1970–1977: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: National income
simpledes: National income aims to measure the total income available to the residents of a given country. It is equal to the gross domestic product (the total value of goods and services produced on the territory of a given country during a given year), minus fixed capital used in production processes (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads) plus the net foreign income earned by residents in the rest of the world.// National income has many limitations, however it is the only income concept that has an internationally agreed definition (established by the United Nations System of National Accounts, see SNA 2008). We thus use it as our reference concept (after corrections to include income hidden in tax havens). // The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [National income]=[Net domestic product]+[Net foreign income]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. shortname: Property income paid from the rest of the world

shortname: Taxes on products
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

shortname: National income price index

longtype: Indices
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

method: We cumulate inflation rates from the following sources; 1970-2018: GDP deflator from the UN SNA; 2019: last inflation value carried forward.

shortname: Consumption of fixed capital
simpledes: Consumption of fixed capital of national economy is the decline in total value of fixed assets (e.g. roads, machines) which are owned and used by a producer. In other words, the amounts required to maintain the quality of fixed assets from a year to another. The decline in  value is a result of physical deterioration, normal obsolescence or normal accidental damage.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

shortname: Gross domestic product
simpledes: Gross domestic product is the total value of goods and services produced by the national economy.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://unstats.un.org/unsd/snaama/Introduction.asp[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]United Nations National Accounts Main Aggregates Database[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: We use the GDP level in 2018 from: [URL][URL_LINK]http://unstats.un.org/unsd/snaama/Introduction.asp[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]United Nations National Accounts Main Aggregates Database[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. Then we cumulate growth rates from the following sources; 1970–2019: [URL][URL_LINK]http://unstats.un.org/unsd/snaama/Introduction.asp[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]United Nations National Accounts Main Aggregates Database[/URL_TEXT][/URL].

shortname: Net domestic product
simpledes: Net domestic product is the total value of the goods and services produced in a country, minus the value of the fixed capital used up in production (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads).The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net domestic product]=[Gross domestic product]-[Consumption of fixed capital of national economy]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2019: estimated from other components. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Net foreign income
simpledes: Net foreign income is the difference between the total value of a country's citizens and companies earned abroad, and the total value of foreign citizens and overseas companies earned in that country.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net foreign income]=[Property income received from abroad]-[Property income paid abroad]+[Compensation of employees received from abroad]-[Compensation of employees paid to rest of the world]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL] for methodological explanations. method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2013–2019: extrapolated from last available year; 1995–2012: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1990–1994: extrapolated from last available year; 1984–1989: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1978–1983: extrapolated from last available year; 1970–1977: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: National income
simpledes: National income aims to measure the total income available to the residents of a given country. It is equal to the gross domestic product (the total value of goods and services produced on the territory of a given country during a given year), minus fixed capital used in production processes (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads) plus the net foreign income earned by residents in the rest of the world.// National income has many limitations, however it is the only income concept that has an internationally agreed definition (established by the United Nations System of National Accounts, see SNA 2008). We thus use it as our reference concept (after corrections to include income hidden in tax havens). // The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [National income]=[Net domestic product]+[Net foreign income]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.

Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Property income paid from the rest of the world
simpledes: Property income paid abroad is the total value of payments made by the national economy accruing to property owners as remuneration for using their property.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Capital income paid to the rest of the world]=[Foreign direct investment income paid to the rest of the world]+[Portfolio and other income paid to the rest of the world]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

shortname: Net secondary income of households and NPISH
technicaldes: [Net secondary income of households and NPISH]=[Net primary income of households and NPISH]-[Direct taxes]+[Social benefits other than social transfers in kind]

shortname: Population

method: Total 2017 population estimated by extending past year observed population growth rate. Data on other years comes from the UN World Population Prospects (2015)

method: We extrapolate the PPP from the latest ICP (2011) using the evolution of the price index relative to the reference country.
